newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - Nov 6.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-PRESS DIGEST-Australian Business News - Nov 6.

text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

According to a report issued by investment bank SBC Warburg Australia yesterday, Australia's superannuation boom and intense new competition for home loan business will lead to the A$12 billion market in asset-backed securities rivalling the total borrowing requirement of all State Governments within three years. Page 1.

As its market share sits at around 40 per cent, New Zealand-based brewer Lion Nathan will launch its new marketing strategy tomorrow in a bid to win back market share from arch-rival Foster's Brewing Group. The strategy will be based on the relaunch of Hhn Premium as a national product, which has so far only been promoted in New South Wales. Page 1.

According to a report by Dr Roy Green and other economists at the University of Newcastle's Employment Studies Centre, growing wages dispersion in Australia will undermine productivity and efficiency in the longer term, leading the economy down a path of low wages and low productivity. The report was prepared to assist the Construction, Forestry, Mining and Energy Union's claim for an arbitrated pay rise of A$60 a week over two years for building workers. Page 7.

Ansett Holdings Ltd's annual report has revealed a drastic turnaround in the airline's fortunes, with Ansett recording an operating loss of A$18.6 million for 1995-96 - its worst result in five years. Despite posting record profits of A$209.2 million only two years ago, Ansett has been affected by intense competition from Qantas, fleet problems and operating troubles at Sydney Airport. Page 21.

Large increases in income from life premiums and investment business have boosted Mercantile Mutual's fund inflow for the year to September 1996 by 47 per cent to A$1.5 billion. Managing director Rod Atfield said yesterday the growth did not include the mounts lumped in with the recent acquisitions of Pacific Mutual, RetireInvest, Adviser Group and Bleakleys. Page 21.

After Federal Treasurer Peter Costello last week gave the go ahead to KPN's A$2 billion takeover bid for TNT Ltd, the Dutch postal and telecommunications group has raised its stake in TNT to just under 20 per cent, buying another 3.25 million ordinary shares, representing 2.3 per cent of the issued ordinary shares, in the market at up to A$2.44 a share. Page 22.
THE AUSTRALIAN

The Australian Broadcasting Authority may move to stop Canadian group CanWest exercising its pre-emptive right to buy a five per cent, A$59 million stake in Network Ten from John Singleton Advertising which was put on the market three weeks ago. Page 35.

The Fraud Enforcement Agency of New South Wales has been called on to investigate the circumstances surrounding the liquidation of Combined Australia Superannuation Scheme Pty Ltd, the trustee of the A$9 million CASS Superannuation Fund, soon after the resignation of the CASS administrator. Page 35.

In anticipation of an expected announcement this morning of a cut in short-term interest rates by between 50 basis points and 75 basis points following yesterday's Reserve Bank monthly board meeting, Australian financial markets reached boiling point yesterday as investors snapped up bonds and sold the dollar. Page 35.

There are doubts over the future of the A$1.4 billion Mid West Iron and Steel project, a joint venture between listed Kingstream Resources NL and Taiwan's An Feng, after West Australian Resources Development Minister Barnett said State Cabinet had given broad support to the development, but had doubts over the plant's location. Page 37.

Bank of Queensland Ltd directors Graham Tucker and Ted Ranson opted to retire yesterday rather than force the State Government, which has put up three new board nominees to represent its interests in the bank, to use its 44.5 per cent
stake to vote them of the board next month. Page 37.

According to unlisted airline Ansett Australia's annual report, released yesterday, the group recorded an operating loss of A$18.6 million in 1995-96, a result which is at the high end of industry estimates for Ansett. Page 37.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

Although at an initial meeting with Canadian media proprietor Conrad Black, Prime Minister John Howard gave no specific commitments to change existing foreign ownership policies, Black says he is hopeful of his company, the London-based Telegraph Group, bing permitted to increase its stake in John Fairfax Holdings. Page 29.

Describing itself as "Australia's only public conservation company", Adelaide-based Earth Sanctuaries, which owns and manages a number of eco-tourist assets, has just released its 1995-96 annual report, which features a new way of describing
its financial success. It includes one conventional financial set of accounts and one that provides an economic analysis of the environment. Page 29.

As three groups - Lend Lease Corp, the ANZ and a joint venture between Commonwealth Financial Services and Westfield Holdings - are believed to be left in the race for Commonwealth Funds Management, which has A$7 billion under management, the Federal Government yesterday agreed to fast-track legislation to sell CFM in an effort to ease concerns of its employees. Page 29.

Ansett Holdings executive chairman Ken Cowley said in the annual report, released yesterday, the airline's operating loss of A$18.6 million before abnormals and tax for the 1996 financial year, due to increased costs from domestic and international expansion, was clearly "unsatisfactory" when compared with a profit of A$98.5 million last year. Page 31.

The Commonwealth Bank went into damage control yesterday as a mass-mailed six-page letter from property developer Davridge Pty Ltd, outlining serious allegations against the bank over the cancellation of a A$3.5 million loan, hit the desks of Federal and tate MPs, heads of Australia's top 1,000 public companies and of the top 500 private companies. Page 31.

Dissident convertible noteholders in Ampolex are contending that the recent settlement of litigation of the conversion rate on the notes conferred a benefit to Guinness Peat Group and County NatWest which was not offered to other noteholders, and are holding out for a higher offer from Mobil Corp, despite advise from the Australian Securities Commission to accept Mobil's A$7-a-note offer. Page 31.
THE AGE

The Reserve Bank is expected to announce an interest rate cut of up to one percentage point today in a move which is likely to boost the bond and share markets and to be taken up immediately by the private banks, which are in an intense battle with non-bank home loan providers. The Reserve Bank met yesterday to consider a cut, following a month of bad economic news, including weak figures on job vacancies, employment, housing and retail sales.

Family businesses will be advised on issues such as succession, the role of non-family executives, remuneration and capital raising in regular seminars, lectures and workshops, following the launch of the Family Business Council by Victorian Premier Jeff Lennett next week. The council will be chaired by Smorgon Consolidated Industries director David Smorgon and includes trucking magnate Lindsay Fox, Coles Myer director Martyn Myer and Sussan clothing group head Naomi Milgrom. Page C2.

Following today's launch of Telstra's new product "Big Pond", customers will be able to have their Internet service charged on their regular telephone bill. The new service will replace a range of Telstra Internet services including the former Microsoft joint venture called On Australia. Page C3.

After selling a 999-year ground lease at Bluewater shopping centre near London to a syndicate of the property arms of Lloyds Leasing and Barclays Mercantile Business Finance and Royal Bank Leasing for A$750 million, Lend Lease Corporation is considering the possibility of selling the A$1.4 billion shopping centre into
a listed property trust. Page C3.

Lihir Gold chairman Ross Garnaut yesterday ruled out suggestions that the company's Papua New Guinea mine may be expanded and begin operations months ahead of schedule, saying the claims were "speculative and potentially misleading". Garnaut said if the timing and scale of the project were to change from the plan set out in the 1995 prospectus, then shareholders and stock exchanges would have to be notified. Page C3.

After receiving clearance from the Foreign Investment Review Board to increase its stake in TNT Ltd from the 15 per cent limit placed on foreign corporations to the 20 per cent limit imposed on it as a bidding company, Royal PTT Nederland NV (KPN) yesterday acquired more than 13 million TNT shares, taking its stake in the Australian transport group to 19.6 per cent.
Page C3.
-- Sydney Newsroom 61-2 373-1800
